carriageway_label.description:
Carriageway Label record a carriageway label for each section of the road to distinguish which carriageway is being coded. 

Undivided vs. divided carriageways. Divided (dual) carriageways are surveyed in both directions, but undivided (single) carriageway roads are recorded in one direction only, even if the traffic is two-way. What is considered divided and undivided depends on the median type and its length:
• Divided carriageways are those that physically separate opposing traffic flows by either a barrier or a wide physical median continuously* for 400m or more. (*This can include gaps in the median at intersections, but not other gaps in the median). 
• An undivided carriageway has no physical separation between opposing traffic flows or physically separates traffic for a section of less than 400m. How do I code a one-way street? One-way roads must be coded as undivided and the ‘Median type’ set to one-way

How do I code a service road? Service roads must be coded separately from the main carriageways. Code service roads the same way as standard roads. How do I code a bus or transit lane? If a bus or transit lane is part of the main carriageway, code it as part of the carriageway (see instructions on coding transit lanes under ‘Number of lanes’). Where there is a dedicated, separated carriageway for buses, these should be coded as divided or undivided carriageways separate from the main carriageway.
carriageway_label.coding:
The coding for the Carriageway Label is as follows: 
1. Divided carriageway in one direction. 
2. Divided carriageway in the opposite direction (to carriageway in carriageway 1).
3. Undivided carriageway (in both directions or in one way)
4. Segregated motorcycle paths adjacent to the main carriageway.

speed_limit.description:
Speed Limit records the actual posted numerical speed limit for general traffic and for motorcycles and trucks. If differential speed limits are not present for motorcycles and trucks, record these as the same as the speed limit for general traffic. Do not attempt to record the speed of vehicles using the road.

Temporary and other speed limit signs: If no speed limit is posted, or there is a state/national limit sign, the default speed limit of 80 Km/h for that type of road should be used. Do not record temporary speed limits at road works or school zones. Do not record advisory speeds.
speed_limit.coding:
The coding for Speed Limit is as follows: 
1. 30 Km/h
3. 40 Km/h
5. 50 Km/h
7. 60 Km/h
9. 70 Km/h
11. 80 Km/h
13. 90 Km/h
15. 100 Km/h
17. 110 Km/h
19. 120 Km/h
21. 130 Km/h
23. 140 Km/h
25. 150 Km/h

speed_differential.description: Speed differential records if the difference in speed (operating or speed limit) between cars and trucks and/or cars and motorcycles exceeds 20km/h or 12mph.
speed_differential.coding:
The coding for Speed differential is as follows: 
1. Not Present: The difference in operating speed or speed limit is equal to or less than 20km/h or 12mph.
2. Present: The difference in operating speed or speed limit is greater than 20km/h or 12mph.

Speed_management.description: Speed management records the presence of road infrastructure features that will typically reduce the operating speed by 5km/h to 10km/h below the speed limit. Features may include curb build-outs, speed humps, raised tables, entry treatments, speed cushions, chicanes, and modified intersections. Do not record roundabouts or mini-roundabouts. Do not record speed cameras. Speed cameras are only considered effective tools for enforcing the posted speed, not reducing it to below the posted speed
Speed_management.coding:
The coding for Speed management is as follows: 
1. Not present: No speed management features are present.
2. Present: Speed management features present and sufficient to reduce the operating speed by 5-10km/h below the speed limit.

number_of_lanes.description:
The number of lanes records the number of traffic lanes in the direction of travel. This attribute is used to record the configuration of lanes on the carriageway being coded. Do not code: 
• Changes over short lengths of road less than 400m. 
• Turning lanes at intersections. 
Do code: 
• Bus and transit lanes that are part of the main carriageway. See ‘Carriageway label’ for more information. 
If no lane markings are present, the total road width should be divided by the number of traffic streams to determine the number of lanes.
number_of_lanes.coding:
The coding for the number of lanes is as follows: 
1. One lane in the direction of travel.
2. Two lanes in the direction of travel. 
3. Three lanes in the direction of travel.
4. Four or more lanes in the direction of travel.
5. Two lanes in one direction and one in the other direction (For undivided roads only).
6. Three lanes in one direction and two in the other direction (For undivided roads only).

lane_width.description:
Lane width records the distance from the center of the edge line to the center of the adjacent lane marking. If the road has no edge line, the lane width is measured from the edge of the pavement to the adjacent lane marking. For roads with one lane in each direction, the adjacent lane marking will be the center line. Where lane width varies, record the narrowest lane width. If no lane markings are present, the total road width should be divided by the number of traffic streams to determine the lane width.

Lane width approximations 
In the absence of exact lane measurements, lane width can be approximated using typical vehicle sizes. For estimation, the typical widths of vehicles are as follows: Truck or bus = 2.5m Tractor = 2.3m Van/minibus = 2m Family car = 1.8m Light 3- or 4-wheeled motorized vehicle = 1.2m. A truck or lorry would struggle to fit in a narrow lane, comfortably fit in a medium lane, and have ample space on each side in a wide lane.
lane_width.coding:
The coding for the Lane width is as follows: 
1. Wide lane (land width is larger than 3.25 m)
2. Medium lane (land width is from 2.75 m to 3.25 m)
3. Narrow lane (land width is less than 2.75 m)

quality_of_curve.description: Quality of curve records how easy it is to judge how sharp a curve is and if it can be driven safely. The quality of the curve will reflect the extent to which signs and markings help the driver to judge the correct curvature, and the sight distance in advance of, and around, the curve. A practical indication of the quality of the curve might be whether the driver needs to adjust speed suddenly or unexpectedly on the approach to, or within the curve. This may occur even though there has been an attempt through signing to warn the driver of extra risk.
quality_of_curve.coding:
The coding for the Quality of curve  is as follows: 
The quality of the curve is coded as follows:
1. Adequate: Signing, marking and sight distance enable a driver to judge curvature. Curves of adequate quality may incorporate chevron alignment markers (CAMs) or other reflective hazard markers.
2. Poor: A curve where rapid or unexpected speed adjustments are needed to negotiate the curve, and there is a lack of advanced signing and/or missing or poorly maintained road markings. 
3. The road is straight or gently curving.

median_type.description:
The median type records the road infrastructure feature that separates the two opposing traffic flows for both divided and undivided carriageways. Do not record defective safety barriers. This includes barriers of insufficient height, made of sub-standard materials, or broken, damaged or poorly maintained barriers. Median fencing used to control traffic and pedestrian movement, but that would not withstand vehicle impact, can be recorded as ‘flexible posts’. If the road is undivided, has two directions of travel, and has no markings, it should be recorded as Median type = Centre line only; Delineation = Poor.

The median type is the road infrastructure feature that separates the two opposing traffic flows for both divided and undivided carriageways.  
Do not record defective safety barriers. This includes barriers of insufficient height, made of sub-standard materials, or broken, damaged or poorly maintained barriers. Median fencing used to control traffic and pedestrian movement, but that would not withstand vehicle impact, can be recorded as ‘flexible posts’. If the road is undivided, has two directions of travel, and has no markings, it should be recorded as Median type = Centre line only; Delineation = Poor.
median_type.coding:
The coding for the median type is as follows:
1. Safety barrier – metal: Divided road-only. Metal safety barrier that meets international standards. Do not record defective safety barriers. 
2. Safety barrier – concrete: Divided road only. Safety barrier constructed from concrete that meets international standards. Do not record defective safety barriers.
3. Physical median width ≥20m: Divided road only. The defined median of different materials is 20m wide or more. A physical median typically includes a curb or other surface change that would slow an out-of-control vehicle.
4.  Physical median width 10m to <20m: Divided road only. The defined median of different materials is 10m to less than 20m wide. A physical median typically includes a curb or other surface change that would slow an out-of-control vehicle.
5. Physical median width 5m to <10m. Divided road only. Defined median of different materials 5m to <10m wide. A physical median typically includes a curb or other surface change that would slow an out-of-control vehicle.
6. Physical median width 1m to <5m: Divided road only. Defined median of different materials 1m to <5m wide. A physical median typically includes a curb or other surface change that would slow an out-of-control vehicle.
7. Physical median width 0m to <1m: Divided road only. The defined median of different materials is less than 1m wide. A physical median typically includes a curb or other surface change that would slow an out-of-control vehicle.
8. Continuous central turning lane: Undivided two-way road only. The continuous central lane is designated as a turning lane.
9. Flexible posts: Undivided two-way road only. Flexible posts or bollards, but they are not a continuous physical divider. May include median fences installed to control traffic and pedestrian movements, but which would not withstand vehicle impact.
10. Central hatching >1m: Undivided two-way road only. Marked central strip greater than 1m wide. Examples of marking are ladder hatching, stripes or coloured paving. 
11. Centre line: Undivided two-way road only. Single or double central line or marked central strip that is less than 0.3m wide. The centre line can be either dashed or solid and of any colour.
12. Safety barrier – motorcycle friendly: Divided road only. Safety barrier designed to minimise impact to motorcyclists that meets international standards. Motorcycle-friendly barriers will have some form of protection for the supporting posts or legs.
13. One way: One-way road only. Vehicles travel in a single direction with no opposing flow.
14. Wide centre line: Undivided two-way road only. Single or double centre line, or marked central strip 0.3m to 1m wide. The wide centre line may be dashed, solid or ladder hatching, and of any colour.
15. Safety barrier – wire rope: Divided road-only. Safety barrier constructed from tensioned wires that meet international standards. Do not record defective safety barriers.

skid_resistance.description: Skid resistance records the skidding resistance and texture depth of the road surface. Surface texture deficiencies include surface friction issues such as loose gravel, flushing or stripping which could reduce traction for vehicles in wet or dry conditions. The attribute recorded should reflect the general condition of the road for the majority of the coding segment.
skid_resistance.coding:
The coding for Skid resistance is as follows:
1. Sealed – adequate: The road surface is sealed and is expected to have adequate skid resistance performance. There are no visible smooth and shiny sections in the preferred vehicle path.
2. Sealed – medium: The road surface is sealed and has a medium grip surface. For example, the road surface is paved and looks smooth and shiny for up to 20% of the preferred vehicle path. Loose gravel or other material is present for up to 20%.
3. Sealed – poor: The road surface is sealed but has a low grip surface. For example, the road surface is paved and looks smooth and shiny for more than 20% of the preferred vehicle path. Loose gravel or other material is present for more than 20%.
4. Unsealed – adequate: The road surface is unpaved with a relatively good surface grip. For example, the surface is compacted aggregate providing a surface that remains firm in all prevailing weather conditions.
5. Unsealed – poor: The road surface is unpaved and has a low grip surface. For example, the surface is covered in loose gravel, or a natural surface is likely to be slippery in wet conditions (e.g. silt/clay surfaces).

road_condition.description:
Road condition records the condition of the road surface. This includes the ability of the road to provide a level, even running surface that is free from major surface defects that may adversely affect the vehicle path. Record a ‘poor’ or ‘medium’ road condition if defects are present for 10% or more along a coding segment. Defects that should be considered include anything that would cause an impact on vehicle control or path, some examples are: 
• Deformation of the tarmac, including rutting or uneven surface. 
• Holes in the road surface due to loss of material that is sufficiently wide or deep enough to cause a severe jolt or loss of control to the vehicle. 
• Edge defects including any road shoulder seal problems which encroach on the driven lane or that would require small vehicles using the road shoulder to enter regular traffic lanes.
road_condition.coding:
The coding for Skid resistance is as follows:
1. Good: The road has very few or no defects and is adequate for all road users. There is no potential impact on vehicle control or path or on motorcyclists and bicyclists.
2. Medium: The road has a number of minor defects which may result in occasional impact on vehicle control or path or on motorcyclists and bicyclists.
3. Poor: The road has serious defects which are likely to result in frequent or unpredictable impacts on vehicle control or on motorcyclists and bicyclists.

vehicle_parking.description:
Vehicle parking records the extent of vehicle parking along the side of the road. 
It includes parked vehicles and on-street parking spaces (even if no vehicles are present), bus stop bays, taxi ranks, and any other designated places where vehicles can stop on the side of the road (such as emergency stopping lanes) within 2m of the outside edge of the driveable lane.
vehicle_parking.coding:
The coding for vehicle parking is as follows:
1. None: No vehicle parking present.
2. One side: Vehicles park on one side of the road.
3. Two sides: Vehicles parked on both sides of the road.

roadworks.description: Roadworks record the presence of major road construction or road works in progress. Record any construction activities in the vicinity of the road that impact its normal operation, such as temporary speed limits or lane closures.
roadworks.coding:
The coding for roadworks is as follows:
1. No road works: No construction or road works in progress.
2. Minor road works: Minor road works are when all the attributes can be coded accurately even though there are road works. Road works and temporary traffic management may affect the speed of passing traffic.
3. Major road works: Major road works are when the road is significantly changed and the attribute cannot be coded accurately. Star ratings will not be generated for these segments.

delineation.description:
Delineation records the adequacy of road lines and markings. Delineation should inform drivers of road conditions to keep them within the driven lane, aware of road and intersection conditions in advance and in location and provide clear visible indications of the presence and path of motorcyclists and bicyclists where appropriate. 
The delineation is based on a combination of the following factors: 
• Centre lines, lane markers, and edge lines 
• Guideposts and delineators, road studs and hazard markers, and 
• Signage (on the road and posted) within an appropriate distance of the approach. Warning signs must be present to warn drivers of any sudden change in the road conditions, such as lane narrowing.
delineation.coding:
The coding for delineation is as follows: 
1. Adequate: Signs warning of severe hazards, and center and edge markings are generally present and visible.
2. Poor: Signing of hazards, or center and edge markings are generally absent or in poor condition.

street_lighting.description:
Street lighting records the presence of street lighting.

A street light or street lamp is a raised source of light often mounted on a lamp column or pole either on the side of the road or within the median or suspended on a wire above the road to provide illumination.
street_lighting.coding:
The coding for street lighting is as follows: 
1. Not Present: Street lighting is not present or is insufficient
2. Present: A street light is present that is sufficient to illuminate pedestrians and bicyclists.

service_road.description: Service road records the presence of a service road running parallel with the main carriageway. If the carriageway being coded is the service road, record the service road as being ‘Not present’. The purpose of a service road is to link the property accesses and minor intersections together and then join them to the main carriageway at a single point. For undivided roads, record service roads that appear on either one side or both sides of the road.
service_road.coding:
The coding for Service road is as follows:
1. Not present: The service road is not present (or the carriageway being coded is the service road).
2. Present: Service road is present

shoulder_rumble_strips.description:
Shoulder rumble strips record any textured markings running along a road which function to warn drivers to leave the lane on the passenger side of the roadway. Shoulder rumble strips are also known as raised profile markings. This feature provides an audio-vibratory warning to the driver. Shoulder rumble strips will only be found on paved shoulders and should be a continuous, unbroken line. Rumble strips may be either grooves cut into the pavement surface or raised ribs added to the road marking. Raised markers that are spaced between 10-20 cm and serve a similar purpose may also be recorded. Shoulder rumble strips should be coded when a carriageway has rumbled for both passenger-side and driverside edge lines (regardless of whether the carriageway is divided or undivided). Do not record centre-line rumble strips here.

Shoulder rumble strips are also known as raised profile markings. This feature provides an audio-vibratory warning to the driver. They may be a solid line or placed intermittently (similar to a dashed line). Rumble strips may be either grooves cut into the pavement surface or raised ribs added to the road marking. Raised markers that are spaced between 10-20 cm and serve a similar purpose may also be recorded.
shoulder_rumble_strips.coding:
The coding for Shoulder rumble strips is as follows:
1. Not Present: No shoulder rumble strip present.
2. Present: Shoulder rumble strip present.

center_line_rumble_strips.description:
Centre line rumble strips record any textured markings along the centre of an undivided road which function to warn drivers crossing the median. Centreline rumble strips should be coded only for undivided roads where there are structured or milled markings as part of the road marking median. Only record centre line rumble strips where they are present for the whole coding segment, except where an intersection is present. Do not record shoulder rumble strips here. 
Centre line rumble strips are also known as raised profile markings. This feature provides an audio-vibratory warning to the driver. They may be a solid line or placed intermittently (similar to a dashed line). Rumble strips may be either grooves cut into the pavement surface or raised ribs added to the road marking. Raised markers that are spaced between 10-20 cm and serve a similar purpose may also be recorded.
center_line_rumble_strips.coding:
The coding for centre-line rumble strips is as follows:
1. Not Present: The rumble strip is not present in the centre of the road.
2. Present: The rumble strip is present in the centre of the road.

paved_shoulder.description:
A paved shoulder records the width of the safe and drivable section of the road from the edge line to the edge of the paving. Code each side of the road separately. A narrow paved shoulder shall be recorded wherever an edge marking is present even if the edge line is very close to the pavement edge. If paving begins to break up on a shoulder, the paved shoulder width should be measured up to where the edge break occurs. If a road has no markings for a shoulder (no edge line), then no paved shoulder should be recorded, since a vehicle is able to travel to the edge of the sealed surface.

Paved shoulder width on divided and undivided roads For a divided carriageway, driver-side paved shoulder width is the distance from the edge line to the edge of the median. For an undivided carriageway, driver-side paved shoulder width is the distance from the edge line to the edge of the paving on the other side of the road.
paved_shoulder.coding:
The coding for Paved shoulder is as follows:
1. Wide ≥2.4m: Paved shoulder is greater than 2.4m (edge line is present). 
2. Medium 1m to <2.4m: Paved shoulder is 1m to less than 2.4m (edge line is present).
3. Narrow 0m to <1m: Paved shoulder is 0m to less than 1.0m (edge line is present). 
4. None: There is no paved shoulder (no edge line present).

intersection_type.description:
Intersection type records the presence and type of intersections. Intersections should only be recorded once – even if they span two coding segments. Do not record property access points, unless they are large enough that turning bays or traffic signals are present. For more information on how to code urban laneways, see ‘Property access points’. 
How do I code very complex intersections? 
Intersections, particularly in cities and urban areas, can take many different forms. In reality, intersections may have as many as 6- or 8-legs, and be a combination of slip lanes, on and off ramps to overpasses, and staged traffic signals. When coding an intersection, consider how many points of potential conflict exist between traffic flows and the highest risk points. The attribute options below are listed in order of risk from highest to lowest. If unsure between two options, select the one that comes first.
intersection_type.coding:
The coding for intersection type is as follows:
1. Merge Lane: Merge lane for traffic entering the road. Merge lanes typically occur at grade-separated intersections. Do not code filter lanes (intersection channelization) or exit (diverge) lanes where vehicles are exiting the road. Only record the merge lane once – even if it spans two coding segments.
2. Roundabout: Circular intersection that flows in a single direction about a central island of 4m radius or more.
3. 3-leg with protected turn lane: Three-leg intersection or Tjunction with a protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic) but no signals.
4. 3 leg: Three-leg intersection or Tjunction with no protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic) or signals.
5. 3-leg signalised with protected turn lane: Three-leg intersection or T-junction with a protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic) and signals.
6. 3-leg signalised: Three-leg intersection with signals but no protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic). 
7. 4+ leg with protected turn lane: Four or more leg intersections or crossroads with a protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic) but no signals.
8. 4+ leg: Four or more leg intersections or crossroads with no signals or a protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic).
9. 4+ leg signalised with protected turn lane: Four or more leg intersections or crossroads with a protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic) and signals.
10. 4+ leg signalised: Four or more intersections or crossroads with signals but no protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic).
12. None: No intersection present.
13. Railway Crossing – passive: An at-grade railway crossing with give-way or stop signage only (or no signage).
14. Railway Crossing – active: An at-grade railway crossing with a physical device to warn of an approaching train (flashing lights and/or boom gates).
15. Median crossing point – informal: An informal U-turn location without acceleration or deceleration lanes and/or with a poor-condition pavement surface. These median crossings have not been formally designed but rather developed informally over time through regular local use. 
16. Median crossing point – formal: A formal (designed) U-turn location. Appropriate acceleration and deceleration lanes may or may not be present. Record this detail plus the condition of the median pavement surface under ‘intersection quality’. 
17. Mini roundabout: Small roundabout with a radius of less than 4m typically found in low-speed urban areas. Mini-roundabouts have a central circular island that is flush with the road surface (or slightly raised) and are commonly constructed using a white road marking or other coloured surface.

intersection_quality.description:
Intersection quality records the quality of the intersection design, advance warning, signing, and markings. Intersection quality is an indication of how well a driver can anticipate intersection conditions and prepare accordingly. Factors that contribute to ‘poor’ intersection quality may include: 
• Very short merge lanes 
• Poor deflection angles at roundabouts (where the approach means roundabouts can be entered at high speeds) 
• Lack of advance signing and marking on an intersection approach where the intersection is not clearly visible to approaching drivers (i.e. where approach sight distance is limited) 
• Lack of facilities for motorcycles, pedestrians and bicycles.
intersection_quality.coding:
The coding for Intersection quality is as follows:
1. Adequate: Intersection design is adequate. Necessary signing and markings are present. Has adequate facilities for motorcyclists, pedestrians and bicyclists.
2. Poor: Intersection design is poor. Necessary signs and markings are absent, sight distance is limited or obstructed, and/or roads and conflicting traffic flows do not intersect at right angles. Has inadequate facilities for motorcyclists, pedestrians and bicyclists.
3. Not applicable: No intersection present.

intersection_channelization.description:
Intersection channelisation records if there are raised islands or coloured hatching present at an intersection that designate intended vehicle paths. Do not code informal channelization, for example, where vehicles regularly cut a corner or there is more than one entry to a side road. 

Channelization is the separation or regulation of conflicting traffic movements into defined paths of travel. Traffic islands or pavement markings are used to facilitate the safe and orderly movements of both vehicles and pedestrians. Channelization is primarily used to separate turning movements from through movements.
intersection_channelization.coding:
The coding for Intersection channelisation is as follows:
1. Not present: No channelization present at an intersection
2. Channelization is present with either raised or coloured islands that designate the intended vehicle path.

property_access_points.description:
Property access points record the number of commercial and residential driveways and minor access lanes. This includes any points where vehicles can enter or exit the roadway other than public roads. This may include entries to large car parks, parkland, rest areas and laneways. Do not record a property access point which is large enough that turning bays or traffic signals are present. In this case, it should be coded as an intersection. Do not record temporary entries, such as for construction, or controlled entries where gates are present.

How do I code urban laneways? Some cities have extra large city blocks that feature extensive laneway networks, which provide access to local residences and businesses. Entries to these laneways may be considered a property access point or an intersecting street, depending on several characteristics. The lists below give a general guide on when a laneway is a property access point and when it is considered an intersecting road. Characteristics are listed in priority order. 

Laneway characteristic record as an intersecting road:
- If the intersection with the surveyed road has regular features, such as turning bays or traffic signals, or intersecting traffic has access to both directions of travel.
- Access laneway provides through access, serves as a trunk route for other laneways, or provides access to a large area of residential and commercial development.
- Size of two cars can pass or traffic is more than 100 vehicles per day.

Laneway characteristic record as a property access point:
- No intersection with the surveyed features; access to side roads only or only one direction of travel.
- Laneway Access provides limited access to residential and commercial establishments.
- Size of two cars would be unable to pass or traffic is less than 100 vehicles per day.
property_access_points.coding:
The coding for Intersection quality is as follows:
1. Commercial Access 1+: One or more commercial access points within the coding segment. Includes service stations, shops and roadside cafes, small car parks and rest stops. May also include entrances to industrial sites such as quarries or mining sites.
2. Residential Access 3+: Three or more residential access points or an access point that serves three or more residential properties.
3. Residential Access 1 to 2: Less than three residential access points or an access point that serves three or fewer residential properties. May also include minor farm accesses and other minor tracks used by motor vehicles to gain occasional access to the main carriageway.
4. None: No residential or commercial access points.

land_use.description:
Land use records the type of roadside development that is observed on both the driver-side and passenger-side of the road. Only record land use types if they continue for at least 400m, except where there are clearly identifiable shorter lengths of high-intensity activity, such as schools, short lengths of village environment, or localised market sites on rural roads. Any areas of obvious potential high-intensity pedestrian activity should be coded as ‘commercial’ even if commercial activity is not immediately obvious. If in doubt between two land use categories, select the one that appears first in the list of coding options. 

Land use attributes are used to indicate likely roadside pedestrian activity. Land uses that typically induce pedestrian activity are used to predict whether pedestrian activity is likely to occur along and across the road. In determining which is the most appropriate land use, it is important to consider the distance and accessibility of the road to the pedestrian-inducing land use.
land_use.coding:
The coding for Intersection quality is as follows:
1. Undeveloped areas: Open land without shops, housing, industry or farming or where there is no land adjacent to the road. For example, bridges across water, elevated highways (without pedestrian access), overpasses and tunnels.
2. Farming and agriculture: Land used for farming or agricultural activities is present. Do not include open pastures with very low or no activity around them.
3. Residential: A residential housing area is present.

area_type.description: Record the type of area surrounding the road. Area type is coded as being either ‘urban’ or ‘rural’ depending on the level surrounding development. Town limit signs may be used as a guide.
area_type.coding:
The coding for Intersection quality is as follows:
1. Rural: Area outside of an urban area or rural town or village, or where roadside development does not impact the road or where it is separated by a large fence or wall. 
2. Urban: Development spanning at least 400 metres along the road. Small, isolated settlements of less than 400m may be coded as changes to land use where they are sites of high-intensity activity, such as schools, short lengths of village environment, or localised market sites.

pedestrian_crossing_facilities.description:
Pedestrian crossing facilities record the presence of purpose-built pedestrian crossing facilities on the inspected road and on the side (intersecting) road.
Record pedestrian crossing facilities regardless of whether they are at an intersection or not. If located at an intersection, record the facility in the same segment as the intersection – even if it spans two coding segments.
Record pedestrian crossing facilities at intersections on the inspected road and side road as per the examples below. If there are two or more pedestrian crossing facilities at an intersection of the inspected road (or more than one intersection), record the one with the highest risk.

What if pedestrians do not have right-of-way? Do not code marked crossings in locations where pedestrians do not have a right-of-way. Only record crossing facilities which provide some safety benefit to pedestrians such as: 
• Pedestrian-specific signalization (if adhered to) 
• Physical protection by things such as refuge islands, curb build-outs (narrowed crossing points), or 
• Traffic calming measures, such as raised crossings or shared zones (where vehicle speeds are limited to ≤10km/h).

When is a pedestrian crossing signalised? Signalised pedestrian crossings require pedestrian-specific signals. Where a pedestrian crossing is at a signalised intersection, the pedestrian crossing is only considered signalised if: 
• Pedestrian-specific signals are present, and 
• A pedestrian signal phase provides pedestrians with effective right-of-way. 

What is a refuge island? A refuge island must be a purpose-built, safe mid-way stopping point for pedestrians. It must provide adequate space and protection from passing vehicles and be seen by drivers. Do not code poorly designed refuge islands of insufficient width or protection.

Pedestrian refuges on divided roads For roads with divided carriageways, do not code medians as refuge islands. The benefit of a physical median is already taken into account. Refuge islands may be coded if they are provided midway across a carriageway (between bus lanes and general traffic lanes, for example, which further reduces crossing distances).
pedestrian_crossing_facilities.coding:
The coding for Pedestrian crossing facilities is as follows:
1. Grade-separated facility: A physically separated pedestrian crossing that does not bring pedestrians into conflict with road traffic flows. May include pedestrian overbridges or underpasses (subways). Do not code grade-separated facilities if pedestrians cross at street level.
2. Signalised crossing with refuge: Designated pedestrian crossing with refuge island and traffic signals that control pedestrian and vehicle movements. Only record a signalised crossing facility where pedestrian-specific signals are present and provide a pedestrian phase. 
3. Signalised crossing: Designated pedestrian crossing with traffic signals that control pedestrian and vehicle movements. Only record a signalised crossing facility where pedestrian-specific signals are present and provide a pedestrian phase.
4. Marked crossing with refuge: Clearly marked pedestrian crossing with refuge island.
5. Marked crossing only: Clearly marked pedestrian crossing without a refuge island. Not signalised.
6. Refuge only: Pedestrian central refuge island is provided. Do not code poorly designed refuge islands or medians of insufficient width or protection.
7. No facility: No provision for pedestrians crossing.
14. Raised marked crossing with refuge: Clearly marked pedestrian crossing with a raised (speed-reducing) platform and refuge island.
15. Raised marked crossing: Clearly marked pedestrian crossing with a raised (speed-reducing) platform without a refuge island.
16. Raised unmarked crossing with refuge: Unmarked crossing with a raised (speed-reducing) platform and refuge island. Pedestrians typically give way to cars on this type of crossing.
17. Raised unmarked crossing: Unmarked crossing with a raised (speed-reducing) platform without a refuge island. Pedestrians typically give way to cars on this type of crossing.

pedestrian_crossing_quality.description:
Pedestrian crossing quality records the effectiveness of the pedestrian crossing on the inspected road or side road.
If two pedestrian crossings are recorded within one coding segment and are of different standards, record the one of lower quality. If the quality of side road crossings cannot be ascertained from survey footage, record the quality for crossings on the inspected road only.
How effective a pedestrian crossing facility is depends on local laws, driver behaviour and other conditions.

An effective pedestrian crossing is one where:
• Vehicle drivers are required to stop and give pedestrians right-of-way (and do so)
• The facility is clearly visible and can be anticipated by vehicle drivers, and
• The facility is not obstructed by parked vehicles, street furniture or other items.

A pedestrian crossing is ineffective where for example:
• Drivers may brake suddenly or fail to see the facility due to the road’s curvature, speed, downward gradient, poor sight distance or other factor
• Pedestrians are entering the facility between parked cars and cannot be seen by approaching drivers or
• Green pedestrian signals do not provide right-of-way to pedestrians. 

Record pedestrian crossing quality wherever a pedestrian crossing facility is recorded on the inspected road. ‘Poor’ or ‘adequate’ pedestrian crossing quality should consider other relevant attributes such as delineation, street lighting, sight distance, and intersection quality (where it is located at an intersection).
pedestrian_crossing_quality.coding:
The coding for Pedestrian crossing quality is as follows:
1. Adequate: The pedestrian crossing is effective. Vehicle drivers stop and give pedestrians the right-of-way, the facility is clearly visible and can be anticipated by vehicle drivers, and the facility is not obstructed.
2. Poor: The pedestrian crossing facility is ineffective. Vehicle drivers do not stop or give pedestrians the right-of-way, the facility is not clearly visible or cannot be anticipated by vehicle drivers, and/or the facility is obstructed.
3. Not applicable: No pedestrian crossing facility is present.

pedestrian_fencing.description: Pedestrian fencing records the presence of pedestrian fencing or other barriers which effectively control pedestrian crossing flow. Pedestrian fencing may be in the form of safety barriers, regular fences (non-safety barriers) or other forms of barriers such as shrubs and hedges. Pedestrian fencing/barriers can be on one or both sides or in the middle of a road. Do not code pedestrian fencing where there is evidence that pedestrians traverse through or over the fence/barrier. Pedestrian fencing should be present for the whole coding segment except where an at-grade pedestrian crossing is present.
pedestrian_fencing.coding:
The coding for Pedestrian fencing is as follows:
1. Not present: Pedestrian fencing/barriers are incomplete or ineffective. 
2. Present: Pedestrian fencing is complete and effective. Pedestrian fencing can be on one or two sides or in the centre of the road.

sidewalk_provision.description:
Sidewalk provision records the presence of pedestrian sidewalks on the driver-side and passenger-side of the road.
A sidewalk is a purpose-built facility for pedestrians that has an all-weather surface (sealed or unsealed) and
provides a reliable surface and space for pedestrians to walk.
Do not code paved shoulders or pedestrian crossing facilities here.
Do not code a sidewalk that is not continuous over the entire length of the coding segment.

Measuring sidewalk distance
Sidewalk provision is based on the sidewalk’s distance from the nearest driving lane, and if there is a vertical barrier separating moving vehicles and pedestrians. This distance is measured from the edge line of the nearest driving lane to the edge of the sidewalk, including the paved shoulder and vehicle parking (if present). 

What is an informal path? Informal paths include: 
• Observed or evidence of pedestrian flow along the side of the road where there is no purpose-built sidewalk; or 
• Where a sidewalk is partially blocked by vehicles or other obstructions, but where pedestrians are not forced to walk on the roadway.
sidewalk_provision.coding:
The coding for Sidewalk provision is as follows:
1. Sidewalk – physical barrier: The sidewalk is present and free of obstruction, with a physical barrier separating it from the nearest driving lane. A physical barrier must be sufficient to restrain a vehicle from entering the pedestrian facility at the posted speed limit. Depending on the posted speed, this may include hedges and small shrubs, bollards, fences, walls, and safety barriers. Curbs are not considered a physical barrier.
2. Sidewalk – ≥3m from the road: Sidewalk is present and free of obstruction, with a distance of 3m or more from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).
3. Sidewalk – 1m to <3m from the road: Sidewalk is present and free of obstruction, with a distance of 1m to 3m from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).
4. Sidewalk – 0m to <1m from road: Sidewalk is present and free of obstruction, with a
distance of less than 1m from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).
5. None: Pedestrian access is not possible, restricted or pedestrians are forced to walk on the roadway; no discernible sidewalk is provided, sidewalk is not usable or sufficient to cater for demand; and/or pedestrians are using road lanes, paved shoulder, motorcycle facilities or on-road bicycle facilities.
6. Informal path – ≥1m from road: An informal path only, with a distance of 1m or
more from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).
7. Informal path – 0m to <1m from road: An informal path only, with a distance of less than 1m from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).

facilities_for_motorcycles.description: Facilities for motorcycles record the presence of purpose-built facilities for motorcycles, mopeds and other light motorised vehicles capable of speeds of 30km/h or more. For undivided roads, record motorcycle facilities which appear on either one side or both sides of the road
facilities_for_motorcycles.coding:
The coding for Facilities for motorcycles is as follows:
1. Motorcycle path – one-way with a barrier: Segregated motorcycle path separated by a physical barrier or located at least 10m from the nearest driving lane. A physical barrier must be sufficient enough to fully restrict vehicles from entering the dedicated path at the posted speed.
2. Motorcycle path – one-way: Motorcycle path separated from the nearest driving lane by at least a 1m wide curb or equivalent raised surface (no barrier).
3. Motorcycle path – two-way with a barrier: Two-way segregated motorcycle path separated by a physical barrier or located at least 10m from the nearest driving lane. A physical barrier must be sufficient enough to fully restrict vehicles from entering the dedicated path at the posted speed.
4. Motorcycle path – two-way: Two-way motorcycle path separated from traffic by at least a 1m wide curb or equivalent raised surface (no barrier).
5. Motorcycle lane on roadway: Dedicated motorcycle lane separated from the nearest driving lane by road markings
6. None: No specific provisions for motorised two- and three-wheelers.

facilities_for_bicycles.description:
Facilities for bicycles record purpose-built facilities for bicyclists. Only record facilities which are specifically for bicycles (and in some cases, also for pedestrians) that are present for the whole coding segment. Do not code facilities which are being used by motorised or electric-powered two- or three-wheeled vehicles travelling at or above 30km/h. For undivided roads, code bicycle facilities which appear on either one side or both sides of the road. Do not code bicycle facilities that are of poor standard. This may include facilities that are: 
• Inappropriate to a high-speed environment 
• Of inadequate width (for example, where a bicycle is painted onto a narrow and poorly maintained paved shoulder or the existing facility cannot cater for peak hour flows) 
• Not continuous for the entire coding segment or have localised pinch points of less than 1.2m in width, or 
• In conflict with other uses, such as merge lanes, parked vehicles or bus stops.

How wide should a bicycle facility be? The recommended width of bicycle facilities depends on traffic speeds and local conditions. Generally, the minimum width of a bicycle facility is 1.5m and not less than 1.2m at any given point. There should be an additional 0.3m width if the lane is adjacent to vehicle parking.
facilities_for_bicycles.coding:
The coding for Facilities for motorcycles is as follows:
1. Segregated bicycle path with a barrier: A dedicated bicycle path separated from traffic by a physical barrier or is located ≥10m from the road. A physical barrier must be sufficient to restrain a vehicle from entering the bicycle facility at the posted speed limit. 
2. Segregated bicycle path: A dedicated bicycle path separated from traffic by ≥1m raised or paved surface.
3. Dedicated bicycle lane on the roadway: A dedicated bicycle lane separated from traffic by lane markings on the roadway or by <1m of raised or paved surface. An on-road lane should be appropriate to the traffic speed environment; be of adequate width, well-maintained surface, and have little or no conflict with other uses, such as merge lanes, parked vehicles or bus stops. 
4. None: No specific provision for bicycles, or existing facilities are of poor standard.
5. Extra wide outside ≥4.2m: The outermost lane is equal to or greater than 4.2m in width. The lane may or may not have bicycle markings or signage. Do not code the road shoulder or where traffic speeds are 50km/h or more.
6. Signed shared roadway: No specific provision for bicycles, but it is signed as a preferred bicycle route.
7. Shared use path: Bicycles have access to a path shared with pedestrians, which is separated from traffic by ≥1m raised or paved surface.

school_zone_warning.description:
School zone warning records the presence of a school zone. Record the school zone from its start point to end point, as designated by the signs on both approaches to the school, even if this spans several coding segments

What is a school zone? School zones are areas within the vicinity of schools and other educational establishments where school children and young pedestrians are likely to be present in high numbers. School zones are likely to have reduced speed limits for certain times of the day. School zones are likely to have appropriate road signs and markings to make motorists aware of the presence of vulnerable road users such as young pedestrians and bicyclists. Parking restrictions may also apply in school zones.
school_zone_warning.coding:
The coding for School zone warning is as follows:
1. School zone – flashing beacons: A school zone is present and incorporates flashing beacons to give emphasis to the warning signs and appropriate speed limit.
2. School zone – static signs or road markings: A school zone is present with appropriate warning signs. Road markings and speed limit signs may also be present.
3. No school zone warning (school present): School is present but without school zone warning signs or markings
4. Not applicable: No school at the location.

school_zone_crossing_supervisor.description: The school zone crossing supervisor records the presence of a crossing supervisor or warden. A crossing supervisor/patrol assists children in safely crossing roads on their way to and from school. School crossing supervisors often operate during the school community's peak demand period both in the morning and in the afternoon. Actual operating times depend on a number of factors including school start times, pedestrian access and traffic volumes. If the crossing is supervised on an ad hoc or irregular basis, record it as ‘not present’. Local knowledge or site observations may be required.
school_zone_crossing_supervisor.coding:
The coding for the School zone crossing supervisor is as follows:
1. Present: A crossing supervisor/patrol is present. The crossing supervisor may be present throughout the school day or during periods of high pedestrian activity only, for example at school start and finish times.
2. Not present: A crossing supervisor/patrol is not present or only present on an irregular basis.
3. Not applicable: No school pedestrian crossing facility at the location
